Immunization 0..*ImmunizationImmunization event information

URL: http://va.gov/fhir/us/vha-ampl-ig/StructureDefinition/immunization.education.publicationDate

URL: http://va.gov/fhir/us/vha-ampl-ig/StructureDefinition/immunization.education.documentType

URL: http://va.gov/fhir/us/vha-ampl-ig/StructureDefinition/immunization-maxNumberinSeries

URL: http://va.gov/fhir/us/vha-ampl-ig/StructureDefinition/immunization-contraindicated

URL: http://va.gov/fhir/us/vha-ampl-ig/StructureDefinition/doseNumberString

Documentation for this format

element.definition: Describes the event of a patient being administered a vaccination or a record of a vaccination as reported by a patient, a clinician or another party and may include vaccine reaction information and what vaccination protocol was followed.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain any narrative
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource
If immunization was administered (notGiven=false) then explanation.reasonNotGiven SHALL be absent.
If immunization was not administered (notGiven=true) then there SHALL be no reaction nor explanation.reason present

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comment:
Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. 

This element is labelled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation.

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded in formation is added later.

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.definition: An Extension

element.label: STATION NUMBER
element.definition: This Indian Health Service field indicated the hospital location ordering this immunization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.label: NAME
element.definition: This Indian Health Service field indicated the hospital location ordering this immunization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.label: LANGUAGE
element.definition: This is the language translation of this Vaccine Information Statement (VIS).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.label: EDITION DATE
element.definition: This is the edition date of this Vaccine Information Statement distributed by the CDC.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.label: VACCINE INFORMATION STATEMENT
element.definition: This is the name of the Vaccine Information Statement associated with this immunization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.label: MAX # IN SERIES
element.definition: (Optional) This is the maximum number of vaccinations that can be given for this immunization.   Enter the number between 0 and 8 that represents the maximum allowable vaccinations that can be given for this immunization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.label: CONTRAINDICATED
element.definition: This field allows the immunization to be recorded as contraindicated. Reminders will include a check to see if the previous immunization was  contraindicated before creating reminders.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: A unique identifier assigned to this immunization record.
Indicates the current status of the vaccination event.
element.comment:
Will generally be set to show that the immunization has been completed.

This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.description: A set of codes indicating the current status of an Immunization

element.short: Flag for whether immunization was given
element.definition: Indicates if the vaccination was or was not given.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because it indicates that an immunization didn't happen.

element.definition: Vaccine that was administered or was to be administered.

binding.description: The code for vaccine product administered

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comment: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL NOT be used to infer meaning. Generally, at most only one of the coding values will be labeled as UserSelected = true.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.label: NDC CODE (VA)
element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: This is the National Drug Code (NDC) for this lot.
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.label: CDC FULL VACCINE NAME
element.definition: This is the CDC Full Vaccine Name for this immunization.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.label: IMMUNIZATION
element.definition: This is the type of immunization that was given to the patient at the encounter.
element.comment: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.definition: The patient who either received or did not receive the immunization.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: Literal reference, Relative, internal or absolute URL
element.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
element.comment: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the URL conforms to the structure "/[type]/[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

element.short: Logical reference, when literal reference is not known
element.definition: An identifier for the other resource. This is used when there is no way to reference the other resource directly, either because the entity is not available through a FHIR server, or because there is no way for the author of the resource to convert a known identifier to an actual location. There is no requirement that a Reference.identifier point to something that is actually exposed as a FHIR instance, but it SHALL point to a business concept that would be expected to be exposed as a FHIR instance, and that instance would need to be of a FHIR resource type allowed by the reference.
element.comment:
When an identifier is provided in place of a reference, any system processing the reference will only be able to resolve the identifier to a reference if it understands the business context in which the identifier is used. Sometimes this is global (e.g. a national identifier) but often it is not. For this reason, none of the useful mechanisms described for working with references (e.g. chaining, includes) are possible, nor should servers be expected to be able resolve the reference. Servers may accept an identifier based reference untouched, resolve it, and/or reject it - see CapabilityStatement.rest.resource.referencePolicy. 

When both an identifier and a literal reference are provided, the literal reference is preferred. Applications processing the resource are allowed - but not required - to check that the identifier matches the literal reference

Applications converting a logical reference to a literal reference may choose to leave the logical reference present, or remove it.

element.label: PATIENT
element.definition: This is the patient who was given the immunization.
element.comment: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

element.definition: The visit or admission or other contact between patient and health care provider the immunization was performed as part of.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

For this reason, none of the useful mechanisms described for working with references (e.g. chaining, includes) are possible, nor should servers be expected to be able resolve the reference. Servers may accept an identifier based reference untouched, resolve it, and/or reject it - see CapabilityStatement.rest.resource.referencePolicy.

Applications converting a logical reference to a literal reference may choose to leave the logical reference present, or remove it.

element.label: VISIT
element.definition: This is the encounter defined in the Visit file that represents when and where the immunization was given.
element.comment: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

element.label: EVENT DATE/TIME
element.definition: This is the date and time the immunization was given.  This date and time may be different from the visit date and time.  For example, for clinic appointment visits, the visit date and time is the date and time of the appointment, not the time the provider performed the clinical event.   The date may be an imprecise date.   Date and time may be within 30 days before of after the visit date, with the restriction the date cannot be a future date.
element.comment: When immunizations are given a specific date and time should always be known.   When immunizations are patient reported, a specific date might not be known. Although partial dates are allowed, an adult patient might not be able to recall the year a childhood immunization was given.

element.short: Indicates context the data was recorded in
element.definition: An indication that the content of the record is based on information from the person who administered the vaccine. This reflects the context under which the data was originally recorded.
element.comment: Reflects the reliability of the content.

element.short: Indicates the source of a secondarily reported record
element.definition: The source of the data when the report of the immunization event is not based on information from the person who administered the vaccine.
element.comment: Should not be populated if primarySource = True, will not be required even if primarySource = False.

binding.description: The source of the data for a record which is not from a primary source.

mapping.map:
.participation[typeCode=INF].role[classCode=PAT] (this syntax for self-reported)
.participation[typeCode=INF].role[classCode=LIC] (this syntax for health care professional)
.participation[typeCode=INF].role[classCode=PRS] (this syntax for family member)

element.definition: The service delivery location where the vaccine administration occurred.

mapping.map: RXA-27  (or RXA-11, deprecated as of v2.7)

element.label: MANUFACTURER
element.definition: Name of vaccine manufacturer.

element.label: LOT NUMBER
element.definition: This is the lot number of the immunization entered for this event. If historical event, enter lot number (if known) in Comments.

element.label: EXPIRATION DATE
element.definition: This is the date that the immunization represented by this lot number is due to expire, as determined by the manufacturer.
Body site where vaccine was administered.

binding.description: The site at which the vaccine was administered

element.label: SITE OF ADMINISTRATION
element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: This is the area of the patient's body through which the vaccine was administered.
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

element.definition: The path by which the vaccine product is taken into the body.

element.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.label: ROUTE OF ADMINISTRATION
element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: This is the method this vaccine was administered. Select from the list provided.
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comment: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.definition: The quantity of vaccine product that was administered.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.label: DOSE
element.definition: This is the amount of vaccine product administered for this immunization. The units are expressed in the DOSE UNITS field (#1313).
element.comment: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).
element.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement.

mapping.map: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

element.definition: Not allowed to be used in this context
element.comment: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value.
element.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

binding.description: How the Quantity should be understood and represented.

element.label: DOSE UNITS
element.definition: This is the units that reflect the actual quantity of the vaccine product administered.
element.requirements: There are many representations for units of measure and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. I.e. mcg for micrograms.

element.short: System that defines coded unit form
element.definition: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit.
element.requirements: Need to know the system that defines the coded form of the unit.

element.definition: A computer processable form of the unit in some unit representation system.
element.comment: The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.  The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system.
element.requirements: Need a computable form of the unit that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

element.definition: Indicates who or what performed the event.

element.comment: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information. element.label: IMMUNIZATION DOCUMENTER
element.definition: This is the person/provider who documented this immunization by entering the data into the system by whatever means.

element.label: COMMENTS
element.definition: This is a comment related to the patient's immunization.  The provider may enter this manually via the PCE User Interface.
Reasons why a vaccine was or was not administered.

element.definition: Reasons why a vaccine was administered.

binding.description: The reason why a vaccine was administered

element.definition: Reason why a vaccine was not administered.

binding.description: The reason why a vaccine was not administered

element.short: Details of a reaction that follows immunization
element.definition: Categorical data indicating that an adverse event is associated in time to an immunization.
element.comment: A reaction may be an indication of an allergy or intolerance and, if this is determined to be the case,  it should be recorded as a new [AllergyIntolerance](http://hl7.org/fhir/STU3/allergyintolerance.html) resource instance as most systems will not query against  past Immunization.reaction elements.

element.definition: Date of reaction to the immunization.

element.definition: Details of the reaction.
Self-reported indicator.

element.definition: Contains information about the protocol(s) under which the vaccine was administered.

element.label: SERIES
element.definition: This field allows the provider to specify which series of immunization type was given to the patient.

element.definition: Nominal position in a series.
Contains the description about the protocol under which the vaccine was administered.
Indicates the authority who published the protocol.  E.g. ACIP.
One possible path to achieve presumed immunity against a disease - within the context of an authority.

element.short: Recommended number of doses for immunity
element.definition: The recommended number of doses to achieve immunity.
The targeted disease.

binding.description: The disease target of the vaccination protocol

element.short: Indicates if dose counts towards immunity
element.definition: Indicates if the immunization event should "count" against  the protocol.
element.comment: May need to differentiate between status declarations by a provider vs. a CDS engine.

binding.description: The status of the vaccination protocol (i.e. should this count)

element.definition: Provides an explanation as to why an immunization event should or should not count against the protocol.

binding.description: The reason for the determining if a vaccination should count or why vaccination should not count.

element.label: STATION NUMBER
element.definition: This Indian Health Service field indicated the hospital location ordering this immunization.

element.label: NAME
element.definition: This Indian Health Service field indicated the hospital location ordering this immunization.

element.label: LANGUAGE
element.definition: This is the language translation of this Vaccine Information Statement (VIS).

element.label: EDITION DATE
element.definition: This is the edition date of this Vaccine Information Statement distributed by the CDC.

element.label: VACCINE INFORMATION STATEMENT
element.definition: This is the name of the Vaccine Information Statement associated with this immunization.

element.label: MAX # IN SERIES
element.definition: (Optional) This is the maximum number of vaccinations that can be given for this immunization.   Enter the number between 0 and 8 that represents the maximum allowable vaccinations that can be given for this immunization.

element.label: CONTRAINDICATED
element.definition: This field allows the immunization to be recorded as contraindicated. Reminders will include a check to see if the previous immunization was  contraindicated before creating reminders.

element.label: NDC CODE (VA)
element.definition: This is the National Drug Code (NDC) for this lot.

element.label: CDC FULL VACCINE NAME
element.definition: This is the CDC Full Vaccine Name for this immunization.

element.label: IMMUNIZATION
element.definition: This is the type of immunization that was given to the patient at the encounter.

element.label: PATIENT
element.definition: This is the patient who was given the immunization.

element.label: VISIT
element.definition: This is the encounter defined in the Visit file that represents when and where the immunization was given.

element.label: EVENT DATE/TIME
element.definition: This is the date and time the immunization was given.  This date and time may be different from the visit date and time.  For example, for clinic appointment visits, the visit date and time is the date and time of the appointment, not the time the provider performed the clinical event.   The date may be an imprecise date.   Date and time may be within 30 days before of after the visit date, with the restriction the date cannot be a future date.

element.label: LOT NUMBER
element.definition: This is the lot number of the immunization entered for this event. If historical event, enter lot number (if known) in Comments.

element.label: EXPIRATION DATE
element.definition: This is the date that the immunization represented by this lot number is due to expire, as determined by the manufacturer.

element.label: SITE OF ADMINISTRATION
element.definition: This is the area of the patient's body through which the vaccine was administered.

element.label: ROUTE OF ADMINISTRATION
element.definition: This is the method this vaccine was administered. Select from the list provided.

element.label: DOSE
element.definition: This is the amount of vaccine product administered for this immunization. The units are expressed in the DOSE UNITS field (#1313).

element.label: DOSE UNITS
element.definition: This is the units that reflect the actual quantity of the vaccine product administered.

element.label: IMMUNIZATION DOCUMENTER
element.definition: This is the person/provider who documented this immunization by entering the data into the system by whatever means.

element.label: COMMENTS
element.definition: This is a comment related to the patient's immunization.  The provider may enter this manually via the PCE User Interface.

element.label: SERIES
element.definition: This field allows the provider to specify which series of immunization type was given to the patient.
